support.p: rejected monument The Glamorgan-Gwent Archaeological Trust Historic Environment Record: 00809w Margam Mountain
support.note: Described as pale grey, weathered deeper grey with iron staining, medium-grained sandstone...[material] of this type are exposed in the upland area adjacent to the find-site (Redknap and Lewis 2007, 406).
support.desc: The top of the stone has an incised cross with chased edges and one line descending on to the inscribed face (Redknap and Lewis 2007, 407).

layoutDesc.layout: The stone is classified as an ogham stone on a 1971 map of Britain in the Dark Ages but there is no other mention of the presence of ogham on the stone. The stone is inscribed with a Roman-letter inscription in four vertical lines reading downwards.

handDesc.handNote: There is no evidence to indicate how the ogham inscription might have been carved, so the execution technique remains unknown. The execution of Latin inscription is described as deeply cut (or recut?) but is otherwise undetermined (Redknap and Lewis 2007, 407). The Welsh Corpus describe the letter-forms in the inscription as irregular Roman capitals with half-uncial H and conjoined FI and LI in FILIUS...angle bar A inverted throughout. Tight but regular spacing overall; the well-formed S and rapidly formed capital R, finishing horizontally to the right, show an experienced hand used to the scale of monumental inscription...the H and the sickle-shaped G are quite confident but unusual; there seems to have been no preliminary complete layout, for the designer has run out of space at the end, where VEDOMAVI is severely cramped (Redknap and Lewis 2007, 407).

ab.persName:
BODVOCI HIC IACIT
FILIVS CATOTIGIRNI
PRONEPVS ETERNALI
VEDOMAVI

div.p: '(The stone) of Bodvocus. Here he lies, the son of Catotogirnus and great-grandson of Eternalis Vedomavus'.

On the names in the inscription, the Welsh Corpus notes that the ancient British name BODVOC appears on coins of the Dobunni, and Bodvocus occurs beside Bodvacus in Gaul (Redknap and Lewis 2007, 407). The name CATOTIGIRNI is most likely Brittonic the precursor of OW Cattegirn, Pr.B. Catihernus...VEDOMAVI contains W. g≈µydd, 'wild'. This stem does appear as well in ogam, VEDA-, VEDDO-, but the phonetic development of the second element...proves the name to be Brittonic rather than Irish (Redknap and Lewis 2007, 407). There is some debate surrounding the relationship between the inscription and the incised cross on the top of the stone. Some have suggested that the cross was carved at the same time as the inscription but it is most likely a later addition (Redknap and Lewis 2007, 407). On the topographical context of the stone, it is worth noting that the stone originally stood beside a well-defined trackway, dominating the skyline as one ascends the track from Rhyd Blaen-y-cwn (Fox 1939, 36-37). The low circular bank forming an enclosure, possibly with a ditch on the inside, measured some 35ft in diameter. As at Maen Madoc (B50), the inscription faced south (i.e. it was visible when approached from below). There was a tradition associated with the stone that whoever read the inscription correctly would die soon afterwards/within a year of that date (Macalister 1945; Redknap and Lewis 2007, 408).
